metadata.case_name: South Indian Bank Ltd. v. R. Chacko

facts.text: Respondent R. Chacko was working as a clerk in the Coimbatore Branch of the appellant-Bank.
By order dated June 19, 1959, R. Chacko was promoted as Accountant and transferred to the Alleppy Branch.
Pay in new post fixed by order on July 16, 1960: Rs. 120 basic pay in grade Rs.120-10-160 from January 1, 1960; Rs.10 per month CAIIB allowance from August 1, 1960.
R. Chacko joined as Accountant on July 13, 1959.

Application under s.33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act claiming entitlement after promotion to special allowance of Rs.40 under Para 164 Sastry Award for additional supervisory duties; basic pay Rs.95 old grade with increments on Dec 1 yearly (Rs.95 Aug-Nov 1959, Rs.100 Dec1959-Nov1960, Rs.106 from Dec1960), plus Rs.40 special allowance, plus DA; total entitled Rs.4,495.22 for July13,1959 to end March1961; paid Rs.3,637.73; claimed Rs.855.49.
Application before Central Government Labour Court, Delhi Camp at Madras in L.C.A. No.564 of 1961; order dated November 27, 1961 allowing claim Rs.855.49.

Bank's contentions in Labour Court: (1) s.33C(2) application incompetent; (2) jurisdiction of Industrial Tribunal not Labour Court; (3) Sastry Award ceased operative March 31, 1959; (4) respondent ceased to be workman on appointment as accountant.
Labour Court rejected all Bank objections, computed amount due Rs.855.49.
Resolution by Board of Directors dated July 18, 1959 authorizing Accountant (respondent) to handle negotiable instruments etc.; circular-letter same date including respondent's signature.
Document dated August 28, 1961 signed by Agent (Ex.1) listing duties of respondent: almost wholly clerical, except 'other work entrusted by Agent'. No power of attorney granted.
Labour Court found respondent merely senior clerk doing clerical duties with supervisory element, not officer; considered evidence, documents, oral testimony.

legal_issues.text: Whether application under s.33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act is competent.
Whether Labour Court has jurisdiction or matter within Industrial Tribunal.
Whether Sastry Award entitled benefits after ceasing operative on March 31, 1959 per s.4 Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act, 1955.
Whether respondent ceased to be 'workman' on appointment as Accountant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Jurisdiction lies with Industrial Tribunal, not Labour Court; Second Schedule does not cover s.33C(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act s.7, Second Schedule

petitioner_arguments.text: Sastry Award ceased operative March 31, 1959; no benefits thereafter; s.4 overrides s.19(6).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act s.4; Industrial Disputes Act s.19(6)

petitioner_arguments.text: Appointment as Accountant made respondent not a workman; had directional/controlling/supervisory duties; board resolution authorized handling negotiable instruments.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sastry Award para 332, 167; Industrial Disputes Act definition of workman

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to Rs.40 special allowance under Para 164 Sastry Award from July 13, 1959 for supervisory duties, plus specified basic pay increments and DA; total claim Rs.855.49.

court_reasoning.text: First objection concluded by Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan: s.33C(2) application lies.
Second Schedule refers to s.7; s.33C(2) assigns determination to specified Labour Court, not Tribunal.

Distinction between award 'in operation' (s.19(3)) and 'binding' (s.19(6)); s.4 ends operation March 31,1959 but not binding period; even post-binding, award continues as contract by industrial adjudication till displaced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ss.23,29 cease but contract effect remains; purpose of industrial adjudication.

court_reasoning.text: Mere designation Accountant does not exclude from workman; Sastry Award paras 332,167 distinguish officers from senior clerks with supervision; evidence shows clerical duties mainly (Ex.1 Aug28,1961), occasional Agent absence not principal; no PoA; board powers not generally exercised.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Court finding on duties correct; promotion not to undo award benefits financially.

holdings.text: Sastry Award benefits accrue post March 31,1959 as binding under s.19(6) and as continuing contract.
Respondent remained workman entitled to Sastry Award benefits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan
precedents_cited.relevance: Holds s.33C(2) application by workmen lies.
Paras 164 (special allowance), 167,332 (accountants as workmen if senior clerks with supervision).

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Application competence, jurisdiction, award operation/binding as contract; penalties/strikes.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Sastry Award in force till March 31,1959; does not affect binding period or contract effect.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; all Bank objections rejected; Labour Court order upheld awarding Rs.855.49 to respondent.
outcome.relief_granted: Labour Court certificate for recovery of Rs.855.49 upheld.

key_quotes.text: "even if an award has ceased to be in operation or in force and has ceased to be binding on the parties under the provisions of s.19(6) it will continue to have its effect as a contract between the parties that has been made by industrial adjudication"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on award's continuing effect post-operation.

key_quotes.text: "the new contract would continue to govern the relations between the parties till it is displaced by another contract."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains persistence of award as contract.

key_quotes.text: "The categories of workmen known as Head Clerks, Accountants... should prima facie be taken as workmen..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Sastry Award para 332, supports workman status.
